    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-138057-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>When launching and persisting attacks at scale, threat actors can inadvertently leave behind traces of information. They often reuse, rotate and share portions of their infrastructure when automating their campaign’s setup before launching an attack. Defenders can leverage this behavior by pivoting on a few known indicators to uncover newer infrastructure.</p>
<p>This article describes the benefits of automated pivoting and uses three case studies to show how we can discover new indicators. Using a network crawler leveraging relationships among domains, we discovered network artifacts around known indicators and trained a <a href="https://distill.pub/2021/gnn-intro/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">graph neural network</a> (GNN) to detect additional malicious domains.</p>
<p>These three case studies show that defenders can proactively discover attack infrastructure by continuously monitoring a threat actor's evolving indicators. The three case studies covered in this article are:</p>
<ul>
<li>A postal services phishing campaign</li>
<li>A credit card skimmer campaign</li>
<li>A financial services phishing campaign</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this article via <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a>, which deploy proactive threat hunting capabilities to discover malicious URL infrastructure. <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-threat-prevention/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> also provides coverage for the associated samples and other indicators discussed in this post.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/malicious-domains/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Malicious Domains</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/deep-learning/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Deep Learning</a>, <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing/">Phishing</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-138057-_8ff77t70r0pe"></a>Proactive Detection Through Automation</h2>
<p>One of the best ways to defend against cyberattacks is to proactively discover a threat actor's new infrastructure based on known indicators. We can then block the associated infrastructure before they can weaponize it. Using automated detection through a GNN model can reveal hidden connections and allow earlier detection of new indicators.</p>
<p>Figure 1 shows an example of domains <a href="https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2024/04/fin7-targets-the-united-states-automotive-industry" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reportedly used by FIN7</a>, a Russian threat actor we track as Squeamish Libra.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_138062" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138062" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138062 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-636207-138057-1.png" alt="Timeline diagram showing the registration and detection dates of various domains including myscannapp[.]com, thepjscanner[.]com, and advanced-p-scanner[.]com, spanning from August 16, 2023, to September 20, 2023." width="1000" height="413" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-636207-138057-1.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-636207-138057-1-786x324.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-636207-138057-1-1697x700.png 1697w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-636207-138057-1-768x317.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-636207-138057-1-1536x634.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138062" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Registration and detection timeline of spear phishing domains used by Squeamish Libra (FIN7).</figcaption></figure>We discovered an initial batch of domains on about Sep. 19, 2023, that were originally registered a month earlier. Pivoting on information from these domains, we detected the next batch of domains within seven days of registration. Our continued monitoring and correlation revealed the last domain on the timeline only one day after it was initially registered.</p>
<p>The initial three fake vendor domains shown in Figure 1 are:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">advanced-ip-sccanner[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">myipscanner[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">myscannappo[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Based on our in-house content analyzers and third-party intelligence, these domains all hosted <a href="https://bazaar.abuse.ch/sample/ff4c287c60ede1990442115bddd68201d25a735458f76786a938a0aa881d14ef/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a malicious binary</a> named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Advanced_Ip_Scanner_setup.exe</span> posing as an installer for Advanced IP Scanner. However, it was an <a href="https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2024/04/fin7-targets-the-united-states-automotive-industry" target="_blank" rel="noopener">installer for Aranuk/Carbanak malware</a>.</p>
<p>Threat actors often abuse, take advantage of or subvert legitimate products for malicious purposes. This does not imply that the legitimate product is flawed or malicious.</p>
<p>This threat actor also registered other domains to weaponize later. However, we pivoted on the hosting infrastructure and mapped additional domains.</p>
<p>Figure 2 shows a diagram mapping the infrastructure of this phishing campaign.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138064" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138064" style="width: 736px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138064 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-639850-138057-2.png" alt="A network diagram with connections between various websites. Arrows indicate relationships labeled with actions like &quot;redirect&quot;, &quot;resolve_a_to&quot;, and &quot;similarity&quot;. The diagram also shows IP addresses connected to these domains, some of which are associated with the United States as symbolized by the US flag." width="736" height="464" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-639850-138057-2.png 736w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-639850-138057-2-698x440.png 698w" sizes="(max-width: 736px) 100vw, 736px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138064" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Infrastructure behind the FIN7 spear phishing campaign</figcaption></figure>
<p>The domains with the red symbol shown in Figure 2 are the known malicious domains before we expanded the infrastructure map for this campaign. Note that we have omitted some of the nodes and edges in this diagram to more clearly show the relationships between the known domains and newly discovered domains.</p>
<p>We can identify new indicators through automated pivoting on known infrastructure based on:</p>
<ul>
<li>The relationships between different types of indicators</li>
<li>Pivoting on these relationships using GNN</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-138057-_w2b1pf7qq2w5"></a>Relationships Between Different Types of Indicators</h3>
<p>We can pivot on existing infrastructure based on the relationship between different types of indicators. These indicators are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Co-hosted domains</li>
<li>Malware delivery URLs</li>
<li>Command-and-control (C2) domains</li>
<li>HTTPS certificates for domains</li>
<li>HTTPS certificates for IP addresses</li>
<li>Phishing kits</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Co-Hosted domains:</strong> To orchestrate large-scale attacks, threat actors often register numerous domains and rotate through them over time, typically using similar hosting infrastructure. For example, the group behind a malicious link shortening service nicknamed <a href="https://blogs.infoblox.com/threat-intelligence/prolific-puma-shadowy-link-shortening-service-enables-cybercrime/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prolific Puma</a> has registered thousands of domains to evade detection. This group further obscured its activity by abusing shared hosting services. Despite these evasion tactics, strong connections remained between older and newer Prolific Puma domains because they were simultaneously hosted on multiple IP addresses.</p>
<p><strong>Malware delivery URLs:</strong> Threat actors occasionally use different URLs to distribute the same malware file. Pivoting on a malware file can reveal new delivery URLs from a different source.</p>
<p><strong>C2 domains:</strong> Malware binaries can connect to multiple C2 domains, either simultaneously or rotating over time. Investigating these domains can reveal a history of IP addresses hosting the servers using these domains.</p>
<p><strong>HTTPS certificates for domains:</strong> <a href="https://sectigostore.com/page/what-is-ssl-server-certificate/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SSL or TLS certificates</a> are used by web servers for identity validation and establishing secure HTTPS connections. All modern web browsers require a valid certificate for HTTP traffic, and phishing websites must have a valid certificate to successfully impersonate a legitimate brand. To automate and scale a campaign, threat actors often acquire these certificates in bulk. Therefore, we can pivot on the fingerprints (sometimes called thumbprints) of these certificates to find other domains from the same campaign or threat actor.</p>
<p><strong>HTTPS certificates for IP addresses:</strong> Since domains are used by servers hosted on IP addresses, these SSL/TLS certificates also apply to the associated IP address. In some cases, a web server or URL might not have a domain name and will use an IP address directly. Either way, we can search for fingerprints of HTTPS certificates across different IP addresses to discover additional infrastructure. For example, since the Russian invasion of Ukraine, multiple IP addresses hosting content from Russian threat actor <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/trident-ursa/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Trident Ursa</a> had the <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/search/entity%253Aip%2520ssl_thumbprint%253A07eee6e893766e8bcc4a711abfdf201ee2920799?type=ips" target="_blank" rel="noopener">same fingerprint</a> for self-signed certificates used during HTTPS traffic.</p>
<p><strong>Phishing kits:</strong> Phishing kits are often discovered in the wild as ZIP archives that contain templates used to create phishing sites that impersonate login pages of a famous company or brand. Criminals often purchase these through phishing-as-a-service operations like <a href="https://www.trendmicro.com/en_se/research/23/i/revisiting-16shop-phishing-kit-trend-interpol-partnership.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">16shop</a>. They can then deploy the same phishing kit to multiple domains and their associated servers. We can identify these by searching for all domains associated with a particular phishing kit.</p>
<p>For an ongoing campaign, we can examine the relationships between these different types of indicators to discover new infrastructure. This is a time-consuming process if done manually, but we can automate the analysis through methods like GNN.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138057-_2xm3eeieqt1n"></a>Pivoting Through GNN</h3>
<p>A single correlation or association between two malicious domains does not necessarily mean these are part of the same campaign. For example, domains hosted on servers using the same IP address could be an example of shared hosting, where hundreds of domains use the same IP address.</p>
<p>However, multiple associations between two malicious domains indicate a shared infrastructure. For example, two domains having the following qualities indicate they are most likely part of the same campaign:</p>
<ul>
<li>Shared same hosting provider</li>
<li>Distribution of the same malware file</li>
<li>Registration through the same registrar on the same day</li>
</ul>
<p>The more associations, the stronger the relationship between the domains.</p>
<p>We can leverage this insight to gather as many correlations as possible between different domains and determine which are part of the same campaign. In addition to the indicators we've already discussed, further attributes like lexical patterns, hosting duration and content structure can also solidify the relationships between domains.</p>
<p>Using this insight, we can pivot from a small, seed set of known indicators to discover additional network artifacts. We do this for our internal detection by training a <a href="https://distill.pub/2021/gnn-intro/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GNN</a> classifier. Figure 3 shows a high-level flow chart of our pipeline.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138066" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138066" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138066 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-642978-138057-3.png" alt="Flowchart depicting the process of detecting malicious domains using a GNN Classifier. It starts with 'Seed Domains', moves to 'Graph Construction', then 'Feature Extraction', leading to the 'GNN Classifier' which classifies domains into 'Malicious Domains' or 'Benign Domain', with an additional input labeled 'Labeled Domain Injection'. The image includes the Palo Alto Networks and Unit 42 logo lockup." width="700" height="248" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-642978-138057-3.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-642978-138057-3-786x279.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-642978-138057-3-1920x681.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-642978-138057-3-768x272.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-642978-138057-3-1536x545.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138066" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. A high-level flow chart of our neural network pipeline to detect malicious domains.</figcaption></figure>
<p>From the seed domains, we construct a graph that expands the information to include other known network artifacts. This enriches each graph node with <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/computer-science/discriminative-feature" target="_blank" rel="noopener">discriminating features</a>.</p>
<p>We extract these features to train a GNN classifier to detect new domains with high confidence. You can learn more about our approach in our recent <a href="https://www.virusbulletin.com/conference/vb2024/abstracts/proactively-hunting-low-reputed-infrastructure-used-large-cybercrimes-and-apts/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Virus Bulletin 2024 talk</a> and <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/3678890.3678925" target="_blank" rel="noopener">recent research publication [PDF]</a> for the RAID 2024 International Conference.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138057-_mtoryf1gvs98"></a>Case Studies</h2>
<p>We have used our GNN approach for detection during the past several months. The results indicate that threat actors tend to progressively register new domains over time. The attackers often reuse hosting infrastructure and domains, often using many domains during a short time window.</p>
<p>The following three case studies provide examples of this threat actor behavior.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138057-_a0f0k0kmprqh"></a>Postal Service Phishing</h3>
<p>We have tracked a large network of <a href="https://krebsonsecurity.com/2023/10/phishers-spoof-usps-12-other-natl-postal-services/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">malicious infrastructure used for phishing websites</a> impersonating national and private postal/package delivery services worldwide. Starting with a few hundred malicious domains, we've identified nearly 4,000 domains hosted on approximately 1,200 IP addresses linked to this campaign over the past year</p>
<p>This campaign has impersonated postal services in many countries, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>The U.S.</li>
<li>Canada</li>
<li>Israel</li>
<li>India</li>
<li>Pakistan</li>
<li>The UK</li>
<li>Spain</li>
<li>Korea</li>
<li>Singapore</li>
<li>Australia</li>
<li>Ireland</li>
<li>Dominican Republic</li>
<li>Mexico</li>
<li>Italy</li>
</ul>
<p>Figures 4 and 5 show a partial infrastructure mapping of clusters from this postal-themed phishing campaign totaling 61 domains and three IP addresses.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138068" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138068" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138068 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-646816-138057-4.png" alt="Diagram showing cyber security threats, with clusters of domains targeting Korea Post and Correos Spain. It includes IP addresses which host domains targeting different postal services. The diagram uses arrows and differing colors to represent the connections between these entities." width="1000" height="631" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-646816-138057-4.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-646816-138057-4-697x440.png 697w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-646816-138057-4-1109x700.png 1109w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-646816-138057-4-768x485.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-646816-138057-4-1536x970.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138068" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Infrastructure map of postal-themed phishing campaign, part 1 of 2.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The connected components in Figure 4 highlight shared infrastructure between domains impersonating the Republic of Korea postal service (Korea Post) and Spain's state-owned postal and courier server Correos.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138070" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138070" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138070 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-652006-138057-5.png" alt="Illustration of a network attack diagram showing a central IP address, labeled 43 dot 131 dot 59 dot 41, connected to various clusters of domain names targeting the postal services USPS, Correos Panama, and Correos Paraguay. Each cluster is depicted with multiple arrows pointing towards it, showing the direction of the attack." width="1000" height="594" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-652006-138057-5.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-652006-138057-5-741x440.png 741w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-652006-138057-5-1179x700.png 1179w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-652006-138057-5-768x456.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-652006-138057-5-1536x912.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138070" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Infrastructure map of postal-themed phishing campaign, part 2 of 2.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The connected components in Figure 5 show a shared infrastructure between domains targeting customers of the US Postal Service (USPS), the Panama Post Office (Panama Correos) and the Paraguay Post Office (Paraguay Correos).</p>
<p>We detected these domains between August 25-Sep. 20, 2024. Out of the 61 total domains:</p>
<ul>
<li>33 impersonated Korea Post</li>
<li>18 impersonated Paraguay Correos</li>
<li>6 impersonated Panama Correos</li>
<li>3 impersonated the USPS</li>
<li>2 impersonated Correos Spain</li>
</ul>
<p>These examples show that the attackers use the same hosting infrastructure to impersonate postal services operating in different parts of the world.</p>
<p>In another example, an IP address at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">47.251.0[.]168</span> hosted malicious domains in September 2024 to target customers of the following postal services:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correosesllr[.]top</span> - Correos Spain</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">inposdomag[.]top</span> - Dominican Postal Institute (INPOSDOM)</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">inposdomak[.]top</span> - INPOSDOM</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">usps.postscy[.]top</span> - USPS</li>
</ul>
<p>This postal-themed phishing campaign remains active throughout the year, but we noticed a trend of increased domains and hosting IP addresses from mid to late 2024. To evade detection, most domains have short windows of live activity before attackers switch to different domains, demonstrating a fast-flux pattern.</p>
<p>This campaign has reused IP addresses. For instance, nine unique IP addresses within the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">103.120.80[.]0/24</span> subnet hosted a malicious domain impersonating postal services in September 2023. These IP addresses were inactive until June 2024, when attackers used them to host 11 different malicious domains impersonating postal services.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138072" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138072" style="width: 2048px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138072 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-656307-138057-6.png" alt="Flowchart displaying the progression of initial and associated malicious domains over time from December 1, 2024, to December 12, 2024, with each domain linked to specific IP addresses." width="2048" height="943" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-656307-138057-6.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-656307-138057-6-786x362.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-656307-138057-6-1520x700.png 1520w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-656307-138057-6-768x354.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-656307-138057-6-1536x707.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138072" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Malicious domains impersonating USPS discovered over time</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 6 shows 15 malicious domains impersonating postal services discovered over a span of two weeks in December 2024. Continuous monitoring of three IP addresses associated with malicious domains detected on Dec. 1, 2024 resulted in detection of additional malicious domains as the hosting IP addresses are often reused by threat actors.</p>
<p>The IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">146.112.61[.]108</span> hosted around 160 malicious domains last year and was reused for 11 more domains this year. This included hosting eight domains in September 2024, all targeting customers of various postal services.</p>
<p>URLs for these phishing campaigns host pages featuring the targeted brand's logo, with various messages as shown in Figure 7.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138074" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138074" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138074 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-660396-138057-7.jpeg" alt="Multiple stacked screenshots of browser windows for Brazil, the United States and Australia, displaying tracking details and error messages across postal systems for each country." width="1000" height="591" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-660396-138057-7.jpeg 1801w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-660396-138057-7-744x440.jpeg 744w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-660396-138057-7-1184x700.jpeg 1184w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-660396-138057-7-768x454.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-660396-138057-7-1536x908.jpeg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138074" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Example screenshots of phishing pages from the postal-themed phishing campaign. Source: <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/posts/unit42_smishing-phishing-postalscam-activity-7227072034718015488-uDdU/">Unit 42 Timely Threat Intelligence, LinkedIn</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Examples of messages include:</p>
<ul>
<li>“Your package is on hold due to an invalid recipient address. Fill in the correct address using this link.”</li>
<li>“Your package is stuck at customs due to unpaid fees. Click here to pay and avoid additional charges.”</li>
</ul>
<p>Links in these initial phishing pages lead visitors to subsequent pages that request more personal information or payment details.</p>
<p>In a one month period from Sep. 10-Oct. 10, 2024, we detected 3,211 phishing domains associated with this campaign.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138057-_6exkw74laeb"></a>Web Skimmer Campaign</h3>
<p>We detected a <a href="https://github.com/PaloAltoNetworks/Unit42-timely-threat-intel/blob/main/2024-04-30-examples-of-web-skimmers.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener">web skimmer campaign</a> that continues to affect hundreds of commercial sites, some of which are in <a href="https://tranco-list.eu/#download" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tranco's list of the top 1 million sites</a>. Attackers first compromised benign sites and installed client-side malicious JavaScript code called a skimmer.</p>
<p>Attackers then loaded this code on potential victims' machines when they visited pages from these sites. When victims logged in to the sites or entered their credit card, these skimmers stole the data and sent it to an exfiltration endpoint controlled by the attacker.</p>
<p>This campaign exfiltrated stolen data to domains with names impersonating well-known benign infrastructure. Examples of these exfiltration domains follow:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">apple.com-ticket[.]info</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cdn-google-tag[.]info</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">chatwareopenalgroup[.]net</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">establish-coinbase[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">google-site-verification[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">jquerylib-min[.]net</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ssl-google-analytics[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">staticlitycis[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<p>After detecting these skimmers on a number of websites, we used our automated GNN approach to identify an expanded infrastructure from a group of seed indicators. The detected infrastructure included:</p>
<ul>
<li>Domains that attackers had not yet weaponized</li>
<li>Assets active since 2022</li>
<li>Many IP addresses that were assigned to hosting providers in Russia</li>
</ul>
<p>We identified 65 domains, 815 IP addresses and other indicators associated with this campaign since October 2023. This campaign is also active year-round.</p>
<p>There was a noticeable increase in hosting IP addresses in early 2024 and significant activity in June and July of 2024. Figure 8 shows a map of the infrastructure used for this campaign.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138076" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138076" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138076 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-663775-138057-8.png" alt="Network diagram illustrating various interconnected nodes labeled with different domain names. Each node is connected by lines indicating the relationships or interactions between these entities." width="1000" height="560" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-663775-138057-8.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-663775-138057-8-786x440.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-663775-138057-8-1250x700.png 1250w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-663775-138057-8-768x430.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-663775-138057-8-1536x860.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138076" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Infrastructure mapping for this web skimmer campaign.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The web skimmer map in Figure 8 contains 15 domains and their hosting infrastructure consisting of 249 IP addresses predominantly operated by Russian hosting providers. Attribution is unclear at this time, but some of our current indicators overlap with those previously attributed to <a href="https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/ta569-socgholish-and-beyond" target="_blank" rel="noopener">TA569</a>.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138057-_l0d6pkiyro71"></a>Financial Services Phishing</h3>
<p>Threat actors used a large network of attacker-controlled infrastructure for phishing websites targeting customers of banking and financial services worldwide. These campaigns spoofed financial organizations' webpages to steal personal and financial data.</p>
<p>From October 2023-2024, we identified approximately 5,000 domains hosted on more than 5,600 IP addresses linked to this campaign. These phishing attacks targeted customers of banking services in many countries including:</p>
<ul>
<li>The U.S.</li>
<li>Canada</li>
<li>India</li>
<li>Germany</li>
<li>Greece</li>
<li>South Africa</li>
<li>Kenya</li>
<li>The UK</li>
<li>Thailand</li>
<li>Switzerland</li>
</ul>
<p>Each day, we noticed dozens of domains impersonating not only well-known large-scale banks, but many regional and local banks, as well as platforms for trading and investment. Most of these malicious domains used shared hosting infrastructure. These campaigns were also active year-round.</p>
<p>Figure 9 shows the infrastructure mapping for one of these campaigns. It illustrates connected components for 16 domains targeting customers of various banking institutions across the world using eight IP addresses.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138078" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138078" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138078 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-668110-138057-9.png" alt="A network diagram showing multiple interconnected nodes representing various banking domains. The nodes are connected by lines indicating network pathways, with each node labeled with a specific bank domain and IP address. Different country flags represent the origin country for each, such as Germany and France. " width="1000" height="549" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-668110-138057-9.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-668110-138057-9-786x431.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-668110-138057-9-1275x700.png 1275w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-668110-138057-9-768x422.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-668110-138057-9-1536x843.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138078" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Infrastructure mapping for the financial services phishing campaign.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 10 shows screenshots from five examples of pages for financial services phishing activity.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138080" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138080" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138080 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-671964-138057-10.png" alt="A selection of multiple digital banking interface screenshots. These include a verification code entry prompt, a secure login page, and a bank with online banking login options including account management and wealth management links." width="1000" height="664" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-671964-138057-10.png 1600w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-671964-138057-10-663x440.png 663w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-671964-138057-10-1055x700.png 1055w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-671964-138057-10-768x510.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/word-image-671964-138057-10-1536x1020.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138080" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Five examples of screenshots from phishing pages for financial services phishing activity.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-138057-_gpfwz49w9ju7"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Threat actors launch large-scale attacks using extensive hosting infrastructure, but this infrastructure changes over time as the attackers attempt to evade detection. This article described our automated GNN approach to pivoting on known indicators, so we can discover new infrastructure for active campaigns before attackers weaponize it.</p>
<p>Our three case studies revealed that threat actors share, reuse and rotate their attack infrastructure. They likely implement these changes through an automated setup process. This process inadvertently leaves behind traces of information we can detect through proactive searching.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats in this article through the following products:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> deploy proactive threat hunting capabilities to discover malicious URL infrastructure</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-threat-prevention/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> covers the associated samples and other indicators discussed in this post</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the<a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>Asia: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 00080005045107</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138057-_drqyalii9o6o"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>
<p>The authors would like to thank Bradley Duncan for the thorough technical review of the article, and Doel Santos for verifying the campaigns mentioned in it. We would also like to thank the editorial team including Samantha Stallings, Lysa Myers and Erica Naone for the assistance with improving and publishing this article. The authors would also like to thank Wei Wang for her guidance in development of this work.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138057-_w32rd6vh2322"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<p>Examples of domains used in Squeamish Libra (FIN7) activity:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">advanced-ip-sccanner[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ipscanneronline[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ipscannershop[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">myipscanner[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">myscannappo[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">myscannappo[.]info</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">myscannappo[.]online</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">theipscanner[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of domains used in postal service-themed phishing:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-myposta[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostf[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-myposth[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-myposts[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsa[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsd[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvse[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsf[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsg[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsh[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsi[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsl[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsp[.]top</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsx[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsy[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoparaguayo-mypostvsz[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correosespe[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correoseswe[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correospanamaagobs-csc[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correospanamaagobs-csd[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correospanamaagobs-cse[.]top</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correospanamaagobs-css[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">correospanamaagobs-csx[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">koreapostge[.]shop</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">koreapostma[.]shop</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">koreapostxt[.]shop</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">us-usos-qwtaa[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">us-usos-qwtad[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">us-usos-qwtaz[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">usps-supsrfvw[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">usps-supsrmuo[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">usps-supsrrne[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">usps-supsrrno[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">usps-supsrtys[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uspsepsu[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uspsftpr[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uspsfugu[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uspsgrjp[.]top</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uspsyeay[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uspsygfk[.]top</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of domains used in web skimmer campaign:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">byvlsa[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cdn-google-tag[.]info</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cdn-report[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cdnreport[.]net</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">chatwareopenalgroup[.]net</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cssjs[.]co</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">google-site-verification[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">jquerylib-min[.]net</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">jsmin[.]co</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns1.static5-jquery[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns2.static5-jquery[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ssl-google-analytics[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">static5-jquery[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">staticlitycis[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">woocomnnerce[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of domains used in financial services phishing activity:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">apps.guardiantrustbanks[.]us</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">capitalxpresslogistic.live.firstnationalbank[.]live</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">deutsche-chartered-bank.cloudswt[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">eurobank-stocks[.]us</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">eurobank-stockscom[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ftp.pristineglobalinvestmentbank[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">gcorpfinbank[.]info</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hgsgbank.com.nexcreditunion[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">inncbank.com.nexcreditunion[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">metropoliscapitalbank[.]us</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">oceansharebank[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pristineglobalinvestmentbank[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">standardcharteredbank[.]live</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">truistcommercialbank.live.rhinoswiftdelivery[.]live</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webmail.portal.guardiantrustbank[.]us</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.capitalxpresslogistic.live.firstnationalbank[.]live</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.deutsche-chartered-bank.cloudswt[.]com</span></li>
</ul>

<li><a href="https://blogs.infoblox.com/threat-intelligence/prolific-puma-shadowy-link-shortening-service-enables-cybercrime/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prolific Puma: Shadowy Link Shortening Service Enables Cybercrime</a> – Infoblox</li>
<li><a href="https://www.trendmicro.com/en_se/research/23/i/revisiting-16shop-phishing-kit-trend-interpol-partnership.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Revisiting 16shop Phishing Kit, Trend-Interpol Partnership</a> – Trend Micro</li>

                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of HeartCrypt.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="graph-neural-networks:related-resources:Crypted Hearts: Exposing the HeartCrypt Packer-as-a-Service Operation:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-12-13T23:00:21+00:00">December 13, 2024</time></span>

                    <h4 class="post-title">Crypted Hearts: Exposing the HeartCrypt Packer-as-a-Service Operation</h4>

                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/06_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="A pictorial representation of Cicada3301 ransomware.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="graph-neural-networks:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Repellent Scorpius, Distributors of Cicada3301 Ransomware:High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-09-10T10:00:08+00:00">September 10, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/repellent-scorpius-cicada3301-ransomware/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="graph-neural-networks:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Repellent Scorpius, Distributors of Cicada3301 Ransomware">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Threat Assessment: Repellent Scorpius, Distributors of Cicada3301 Ransomware</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/raas/" title="RaaS" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="graph-neural-networks:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Repellent Scorpius, Distributors of Cicada3301 Ransomware:RaaS">RaaS</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/data-exfiltration/" title="data exfiltration" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="graph-neural-networks:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Repellent Scorpius, Distributors of Cicada3301 Ransomware:data exfiltration">Data exfiltration</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/leak-site/" title="Leak site" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="graph-neural-networks:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Repellent Scorpius, Distributors of Cicada3301 Ransomware:Leak site">Leak site</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/repellent-scorpius-cicada3301-ransomware/" title="Threat Assessment: Repellent Scorpius, Distributors of Cicada3301 Ransomware" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="graph-neural-networks:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Repellent Scorpius, Distributors of Cicada3301 Ransomware:read now">

                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1-786x368.png" class="lozad" alt="Illustrative image featuring two fish and the Pisces constellation superimposed on a stylized, abstract background with flowing purple waves and a starry night sky." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1-786x368.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1-1493x700.png 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1-768x360.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1-1536x720.png 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1.png 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="graph-neural-networks:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups:High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-09-09T22:00:58+00:00">September 9, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-assessment-north-korean-threat-groups-2024/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="graph-neural-networks:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/north-korea/" title="North Korea" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="graph-neural-networks:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups:North Korea">North Korea</a>

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			                 <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:400px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			                  <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:949px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

            <div class="nav-column">
              													<nav>
					<ul class="footer-menu-nav__list"> 
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item nav-title">

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.2' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</body>
</html>
